comments.commentBody:
Vince,

I know lots of people in Toronto. They have to take their children to the E.R. When they get sick because they can't get an appointment at the Doctor's office, others wait months for an MRI, and still others that have a hard time finding a Doctor to take them as a Patiant.

I would like to point out that in the wake of this opposition, and in anticipation of the election row, there is a very fast growing grassroots movement to demand Single Payer Health Care. How do you think these greedy folks would feel if they blew Obamacare and got Single Payer?

Angelito, you better have over $100,000 for retirement in addition to SocSec.
Ben Bernanke has been printing money - How Much? What he's saying ain't the truth. HE WILL PRINT MORE - there is more where that came from.

You are smug thinking your SocSec and Medicare will take care of you, but it will never keep up with RAMPANT INFLATION. I have been on SocSec since 2008 - they have finally had an increase - it barely covers the increase in Medicare charge. For 3 years they have been printing like crazy. That's why China were selling their US Bonds last year. THAT IS WHY EVERYTHING COSTS MORE - not just gas - EVERYTHING.

If you have hoarded GOLD, you should be just fine.

Given the growing number of people who are harmed under our present system, and then noticing that the vast majority of us won't be helped one iota by Obamacare even if it survives, perhaps the most amazing turn of events might be that universal health care gets done by a Republican administration under Mitt Romney.  That would be perhaps the ultimate coup de gras for Democrats who might lose every election for decades after.

As usual, he goes to sleep with the devil in order to advance his agenda. This compromising habit, and never sticking to what he says is why he will probably loose. Too many people, like me, have had it with his lack of real commitment to any cause. I would rather his proposal would go down in flames and defeat rather than compromise on the general concepts and the result is a watered down version with loopholes ensuring profit making for a few, and no benefit for the masses. Wall Street regulations is a case in point.

I have no doubts that tyhe Republican will wreck the economy again and destroy the social network, except I am too old for them to affect my medicare or social security benefits, which I will receive in a couple of years. So, I will be greedy. Let the younger generation, if they care or understand, elect the next President. It is their future that will go down the drain, not mine!

I see that you are so opposed to corporations using their money to influence our political processes that you voluntarily came to this corporate site to immerse yourself in this corporation's political bias for all things liberal, including specific endorsements of political candidates, using real corporate money to do so.
Do we really need the government's approval to call a noodle a noodle? How "Fahrenheit 451" -- rest in peace, Ray Bradbury.

You only need the government's position to call a noodle a noodle if you want to sell it.

My question is why not; instead of insisting that noodles contain eggs but excepting "Chinese noodles," "Japanese noodles," "Japanese-style noodles," "Asian noodles," etc., etc.; just call the other ones "egg noodles"?
And don't put colored margarine on your non-egg noodles.

A few observations on a fun puzzle:

Clever putting "nudists lack" and "shrinking body" together.

Pasta isn't always a noodle, but noodle is always pasta, so I guess the clue can pass.

40A unfortunately brought back the bitterness I felt in being passed over for the list of Hottest Hotties of the 90s. I am trying to get over it, and it doesn't help being reminded of that disappointment when doing a crossword puzzle. Thanks a lot.

Meh - laws can be pretty good deterrents for abhorrent behavior. No, they are not a cure for greed, but my guess is, that even most sociopaths would prefer to stay out of jail and avoid public disgrace (if only because it reflects poorly on their spouses and children).

Give 'em an inch, they take a yard, give half an inch, they'll probably restrain their sights to half a yard.

Pretending the existence of the internes has reversed information assymetry is ridiculous, as is expecting the population of all other professions to master the most minute tenets of finance. How many traders can perform surgery? Rebuild and engine? Gimme a break.

Wags, Mark Wahlberg, soared to #1 due mainly to the way his ad agency had him "Packaged!"

Howie

If this were a Spanish crossword, TAMALE would be a terrible error. But tamale, a backformation from "tamales" is a good English word and is in all the dictionaries.

Are you blaming Will for people mispronouncing habanero (and habanera too, by the way)? I suspect not.

As for political stuff here, I'm squarely with Alan J. Having said that, including OBAMACARE as an entry started it. I would hope we don't get carried away with it but I think we can cut Rijkstra a bit of slack.

It is obvious form your comment about the president that you do not have any intelligence to insult anyway.

I had thought better of Senator McCain but I find his remarks despicable.
That the Republicans would suggest these leaks were politically motivated by Obama, and then to insult the integrity of Mr. Holder, only shows just how devoid of common decency you and your Republican friends are.

David Underwood:

Film makers were given privileged access to "the situation room", in order to assist in making hagiographic news reports and films. Meanwhile, Obama's DOJ is prosecuting anyone who tries to give the public the same information - not because it is classified, but because it is critical in nature.

I think we need to be much more critical of Obama and his DOJ, who have prosecuted whistleblowers, while protecting Wall Street Fraudsters from accountability, expanding the power of our entrenched political class to gain power over popular challenge, ferociously attacking those who would try to perform the important function of critical reporting of the powerful.

Our government classifies ever more information unnecessarily (truly massive amounts are classified for no other reason than to prevent public debate on policy), and uses the selective release of this information to propagandize the public, and use the law as a huge club hanging over the heads of those who would challenge our ever increasing unconstitutional government corruption.

Obama is even more active in this than Bush. That is not partisan - it's a fact. Yes, I voted for Obama - I am not a knee-jerk critic.

Read Glenn Greenwald at Salon.com, and get informed.

The President said: “The notion that my White House would purposefully release classified national security information is offensive,". Lets consider: 1) There is no doubt that classified information was released. 2) Only a small number of senior functionaries are supposed to have access to that info. 3) The leaked info had the effect of benefiting Mr. Obama's image, or at least trying to do so, at the expense of risking agents on the field and that poor doctor in Pakistan now sentenced to 30 years in prison. Are we to suppose that those leaks were not intentional? That the leakers didn't do what they were doing? Or that the leakers were Republicans?
What I find offensive is for the president to insult our intelligence. And of course, with Holder controlling the "investigation" we will never have results before Nov 7, if ever.
Jim: just like that, you accuse Romney and Rove of committing treason? Where is your evidence? What did they leak?
I agree. A special prosecutor shoud be appointed to investigate Mittens and Rove. They as usual have committed treason.

The article in the New York Times last Friday, which started this tempest in a teapot, was adapted from David Sanger's latest book, titled "Confront and Conceal: Obama's Secret Wars and Surprising Use of American Power." It was published by Crown on Tuesday, June 5, 2012.

The Times didn't reveal any information beyond that which was already going to be published in a different medium in a few days. The information appeared in the Times simply because they're fortunate enough to have David Sanger on their illustrious staff.
No, you need to read the Pentagon Papers case again.  Sullivan concerns whether public figures can sue for libel.

The article which started this discussion is an excerpt from David Sanger's latest book, published June 5, 2012. The New York Times made this perfectly clear. Go back and read it.

http://www.nytimes.com/2012/06/01/world/middleeast/obama-ordered-wave-of...

OK. Let's go to the next question. Forgetting about where the classified information came from, what is the responsibility of the publisher who knowingly decides to publish classified information?  Isn't that sort of like treasonous?  I guess I need to go back and read Sullivan v. Times. But maybe there's an ethical element to it too. Particularly when the publisher is a known Friend of Barack. Too hot to publish? We'll see. We'll see.

No doubt this probe will be a "priority" for Mr. Holder, just like those Congressional subpoenas on the Fast and Furious matter. At least one NYT story made it clear the leak of national security information (NB: Iranian retaliatory cyberattack doubtlessly pending) emanated from the executive branch. By the way, don't expect any results from Holder's "investigation" before this coming November.

The Administration thinks the electorate is clueless and easily gulled. The $64,000 question is whether they are correct.
Actually, McCain once did have integrity, but he sold it in an attempt to become president.  Since then his reputation has become fairly well peccable.

Whatever your view of his politics, McCain is an American hero who underwent torture while serving his country in the armed forces.

I'm going to take a wild guess and assume that your contributions haven't quite approached that.

What a joke. Rod Rothstein is a walking cesspool who for a decade has refused to anything about obvious wrongful convictions resulting from the blatant misconduct by his staff, most notably fabricated exhibits by AUSA (now Magistrate) Stephanie Gallagher. No surprise given the culture of corruption he and Gallagher came from under Thomas DiBiagio, who was fired--by a Republican AG no less-- for demanding the political prosecutions of high profile Democrats in the weeks before the 2004 election!  The Maryland US Attorney's office is thoroughly incapable of acting with any modicum of ethics or integrity.
And "sunlight is the best disinfectant."
Well, you've certainly forgotten. The Imperial Japanese Navy and the German U-boat fleet are no longer sinking anybody's ships.

Of course we know what those words mean, those of us who lived through World War Two. We also remember that in his four terms as President, FDR initiated dozens of work programs to provide for the 14 million jobless. It was called the Works Progress Administration--best known as the WPA. And it saved this country, despite opposition from another rightwing Supreme Court and the Republican Party. It was the
Great Depression, and like today's, it was caused by the monumental greed of the Wall Street barons...some of whom jumped from the skyscrapers.

Did this country learn anything? No, we forgot. And it's happening again. And the main players are Obama and
Romney.
Not a single poster here remembers the old warning, "Loose lips sink ships."  I'd guess no one reading this even know what those words mean.  But President Obama and a few other Americans do.

Byron: every leak I read about does the opposite - makes Obama look good. They don't discredit him.
And why do you assume GOP would leak secrets to hurt the country, but democrats wouldn't?
Can't help but wonder if certain GOP operatives would go to the extreme of creating leaks just to discredit Obama.  This might be outlandish, save for the Plame affair.

Yes, that ever-dependable Republican lawmaker Diane Feinstein (D-Cal) is one of the movers and shakers here who are totally outraged.

By the way, is there something in the water on the East Coast or what?

I would agree more readily with your comment if I didn't already understand enough about human nature to know that the 'oppressor' and the 'oppressed' always change places.

You comment : 'Don't let them keep scaring you whilst we are passed by other countries who focus on educating and looking after their citizens rather than scaring their own citizens and blowing citizens of other countries to bits. '

But you're posting from Shanghai? June 4'th just passed this last week. Who is this 'we'? It's true that we blow up people of other countries. Hopefully we won't sink to slaughtering our own citizens. At least not without the guise of war to justify it.

All over the globe we live like animals with no sense of balance or connection. This is what we must change.

Peace to you and yours.
"It is being investigated by top men ... TOP men." (end scene, "Raiders of the Lost Ark")

When Holder says that he has: "every confidence [in the two appointed US attorneys] to doggedly follow the facts and the evidence in the pursuit of justice wherever it leads," he is using "government-speak" to avoid appointment of a special counsel to investigate the leaks.  Holder is their boss and he will keep them on a short leash, directing them to probe certain areas/folks and to stay away -- far away -- from other areas, especially if Obama might be hurt.   Special counsel = "zero tolerance" for leaks and some firings,  whereas appointed US Atttorneys= never-ending investigation but no prosecutions.  See how many fatcats from Wall Street who caused the 2008 financial meltdown who have been prosecuted = (aside from Raj from Galleon) almost zero.
Wiseman: why on earth would Republicans want to leak information which makes Obama look like a hero?
I wouldn't be surprised--they do so want the "disappointed Dems" to sit out the election.
Lisa: why would the Dems be disappointed when Obama looks like a hero?

Did anyone really need an expose to consider the revealed events as having happened? Are you all children?  In any case I want to take this opportunity to reveal that I have good reason to believe that the Republicans were involved in the leaks!
Yep. Same as they didn't after the WMD debacle.
@Richard: Excellent comment.

The President's indignant position "...These are criminal acts when they release information like this" is commentary Nixon would have relished when he was exposed for secret bombing raids in Cambodia and Laos while simultaneously concluding cease-fire accords with North Vietnam.

What gets lost in this 21st century fiasco, is that Congress is complicit in this undeclared war, while Nixon's executive tribe acted alone.

What is even more astounding, is that there is no public outrage, but rather a whirlwind of politicos posturing to save their hides. They need not worry, nobody is storming the castle.

how strange that a man not trusted by anyone can lead an investigation into anything.
strange days.

Rather than spending time and prosecutorial resources trying to suppress the information that the public needs to know about the secret wars being conducted in our name in the Middle East, Mr. Holder and his boss should be directing their underlings in the United States Attorney's Office for the Southern District of New York to forego an appeal of Judge Katherine Forrest's courageous May 16th decision that declared unconstitutional Section 1021 of the 2012 National Defense Authorization Act.  I pray, if the leakers are discovered, that they are not indefinitely detained without charge or trial by the military for "substantially supporting" terrorism, and that this comment itself is not declared to be a "belligerent act."

And while we are at it, let us prosecute those who approved the use of waterboarding and other forms of torture, including the use of stress positions, in interrogating prisoners of war.  Yes, criminal investigations are long overdue.
Agreed.  That's what they said back then.  Where is this same logic now?  Let's change the rules again.

I thought we didn't want to look back because the country needs to move forward?

If not, then how about starting with an investigation into lying about WMDs to get us into a war and the massive bank fraud behind the real estate bubble?
You mean the Republicans might try to sabotage the President?

It’d be interesting—but not particularly shocking, given today‘s political climate and history—if a thorough, unbiased investigation conclusively revealed that the leaks in question emanated from sources hostile to the White House rather from the White House itself.

With that possibility in mind, perhaps all—including myself—who’d assumed that the opposite was true may be well advised to permit such scrutiny to proceed without predicting its outcome prior to its completion.

That said—and under the collective circumstances, Mr. McCain’s proposal that such an investigation be conducted by special counsel is not without merit. Even if it backfires.
